SCAM measures whether AI agents will be good stewards of sensitive information against threats humans encounter every day.
SCAM is an open-source benchmark.
The benchmark tests AI agents' security awareness during realistic, multi-turn workplace tasks.
SCAM v0.1 was released on February 12, 2026.
1Password created SCAM.
The Security Skill is a 35-line system prompt addition that dramatically improves agent safety across all models.
The Security Skill is roughly 1,200 words.
The benchmark shows that without security training, AI agents can open phishing links, pull real passwords from vaults, and type them into fake login pages.
The Security Skill teaches a framework for recognizing when something is off and gives permission to stop and ask questions even when requests come from authority figures.
The Security Skill includes domain verification instructions that analyze email and URL domains character-by-character.
The Security Skill includes social engineering signal detection for urgency, authority pressure, credential requests, and procedure bypass attempts.
The Security Skill includes credential and sensitive data handling protocols that analyze before acting.

1Password released an open source benchmark called SCAM (Security Comprehension and Awareness Measure) to test AI agents' safety during real workflows.
The benchmark tests AI models in simulated workplace scenarios including opening emails, clicking links, retrieving stored credentials, and filling out login forms.

SCAM includes embedded traps that resemble common real-world attacks such as phishing links in legitimate-looking emails, lookalike domains differing by one character, and sensitive credentials hidden in meeting notes.
The benchmark uses official APIs from providers such as OpenAI, Anthropic, and Google.
Models are scored on whether they warn users about suspicious activity, refuse unsafe actions, and whether they proceed with credential sharing or form submissions.
1Password tested eight models across 30 scenarios, running each scenario three times under baseline conditions.
Safety scores ranged from 35% to 92%.
Claude Opus 4.6 ranked highest and Gemini 2.5 Flash ranked lowest.
Every model committed critical failures in every run.
Critical failures include unsafe actions that could lead to leaked passwords, stolen money, or compromised systems.
Gemini 2.5 Flash produced the most critical failures, averaging about 20 per run.
GPT-4.1 and GPT-4.1 Mini followed close behind in critical failures.
Models routinely forwarded passwords to external contractors, entered credentials into phishing sites, and shared secret keys over email.
1Password gave each model a short 'security skill' document designed to improve how agents assess risk during routine tasks.
With the skill applied, every model improved and critical failures dropped sharply across the benchmark.
Several models recorded zero critical failures across repeated runs, including all three Claude models and Gemini 3 Flash.
The skill file narrowed the performance gap between stronger and weaker models.
One scenario produced failures across every tested model where an email contained meeting notes with passwords.

key_quotes.quote: We rely on open source software every day to develop 1Password. It's fair to say that 1Password wouldn't exist without the open source community, so we want to give back and help teams be more productive and secure.

Are you working on an open source project that needs a password manager? How about a secure place to keep and share secrets — social media logins, code signing certificates, ssh keys, etc.? We've got your back: get 1Password Teams free on us.

To apply, you need to be a core contributor for an active open source project that is at least 30 days old. We’ll also accept applications from the organisers of community meetups and events, as well as some conferences.
Projects need to use a standard open source license and must be non-commercial.
If you're not sure if your project meets these requirements, ask us @1Password or opensource@1password.com.
Your membership does not expire. If you signed up before November 26, 2021, please contact opensource@1password.com to convert your two-year membership into one that doesn't need to be renewed.
Memberships cannot be transferred or sold.
We'll review all requests and accept them at our discretion. If accepted, your project may be listed below. Memberships may be canceled if accounts are found to no longer meet the requirements.
SCAM is an open-source benchmark that tests AI agents' security awareness during realistic, multi-turn workplace tasks.
Most benchmarks show an AI a phishing email and ask 'is this bad?' SCAM is different. It tests whether an agent can proactively recognize and report threats during normal activity.
The most dangerous failures happen when you comply instantly and realize the problem after the damage is done.
A matching sender domain doesn't guarantee safety — in account compromise, the correct domain is the whole point.
Be decisive. If your analysis identifies a known attack pattern and the evidence supports it, act on that conclusion. Don't hedge as 'suspicious' when you've already identified the deception.

key_quotes.source: Jason Meller, VP of Product at 1Password
key_quotes.quote: Every frontier AI model can identify a phishing page when you ask it to.

key_quotes.source: Jason Meller, VP of Product at 1Password
key_quotes.quote: But when we gave those same models an inbox, a password vault, and a routine work task, they retrieved real credentials and entered them into an attacker's fake login page.

key_quotes.source: Jason Meller, VP of Product at 1Password
key_quotes.quote: Most AI security benchmarks test whether models can be tricked into breaking their rules. SCAM tests something harder: whether they walk into attacks on their own, the same way humans do.
